ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was a semi-lecture in that Professor Szabo had slides that he presented but discussion was always encouraged. Additionally, the Friday class was a full-on discussion.
Twice weekly lecture format and weekly discussion section, all virtual. Given how small the class was (approximately 10 students), lectures often turned into discussions.
None
Zoom
Also had live discussion section once a week
Two recorded live meetings of lecture but with lots of opportunities to ask questions , and one discussion section.
Virtual lecture and seminar

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned to think about language in a more philosophical way, focusing on meaning. Focusing on both spoken and sign languages helped me better understand how languages are structured and how their semantics work. I appreciate how we were able to extract what language can tell us about how we think about the world from linguistic structures. I also learned what constitutes a true sentence. Finally, I learned how meaning can change depending on who the speaker/listener is and what the context is, and how accommodation allows for better communication.
I learned how to manage my reading assignments

Philosophy of language. Explored topics such as truth, meaning, the context of language, and implicature and pragmatics
The course also has a strong focus on sign language and animal calls.

Knowledge of wide-variety of Philosophy of Language topics. Discussion of Semantics, Pragmatics, theories of meaning, truth, how languages are common/different, and Philosophical commitments of our language use.
I learned how to think rigorously and practiced reading difficult texts.
I learned how to think about language philosophically. Rather than checking theories against ethical or metaphysical intuitions, we checked theories against linguistic intuitions.
Developed philosophical reasoning skills, and fluency in linguistic vocabulary.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Szabo is brilliant and knows how to lecture while fostering discussion. It's also not an insane amount of work, especially for the amount you learn. He knows how to answer questions clearly and efficiently.
Weaknesses: this is less of a weakness and more of a necessary annoyance, but some of the readings are very dense.

Strengths:
- reasonable amount of reading, this gave me time to read carefully as opposed to rush through longer material and not have time to really understand much
- the weekly discussions questions/comments we had to post and the biweekly responses were helpful in making sure I had understood the material we covered
- discussion sections were great for challenging one another's ideas

I don't think this course had any weaknesses
I thought the class was very challenging and the professor graded too harshly

Strength: Prof Zoltan Szabo is quick to answer students' questions. Willing to discuss questions and papers outside of class. We received prompt feedback on our papers and assignments. Three guest lectures! Weakness: I feel lecture time is mainly used to summarize the course reading.

Strengths: Lectures are very clear and really helped parse some readings which I found quite difficult, Prof. Szabo is willing to answer questions and does so convincingly and in-depth, assignments really do make you think about the material and sometimes let you dive deeper depending on interest on the question, fair grading
Weaknesses: Sometimes it was unclear what the progression of ideas always was and why I should care about some of the stuff. Although all the questions are interesting it was unclear what as at stake in some conversations, and also I think my understanding of the material would have been better if stronger through-lines between different lectures and readings were given as a way to set the context.

I liked the lecture/seminar format, and the assignments were helpful. The only assignment that was out of place was the first draft of the final paper -- it seemed to me like it was due much too early.

Strengths = The professor clearly knows what he's talking about, and was really helpful at explaining thoroughly (sometimes more than once) somewhat difficult topics.

Weaknesses = Not many. Material can be dense at times.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the same as I would in a course taught under normal circumstances. If I were to pick one flaw, it would be that office hours sometimes felt rushed, that I wasn't able to engage in conversation with the professor and felt like I had to just discuss the questions I had about the material.

Succeeded:
- recorded classes
- powerpoint presentations in addition to discussions
- Professor Szabo always encouraged students to ask questions

Could be improved:
- attending class was very useful given this is a seminar, so I believe it would be hard for students to stay engaged if they had to rely on recordings
This professor handled the zoom lectures well

It was all pretty good. Lectures were small enough that questions could be taken, and discussion sections were a nice change of pace. I liked that I had to submit questions for discussion section as it made me actually go back each week and reflect on the material which I otherwise might not have so explicitly done.
The virtual seminar ran smoothly
I think things went as well as could be expected. Perhaps more one one one conversation with peers (using breakout rooms) would have been nice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! If you're interested in the material, then it's going to be one of the most interesting classes you'll ever take.
I would recommend this course to students interested in philosophy or linguistics.
If interested in the topic then take the course. Otherwise, it is too much work and too confusing for the class to be enjoyable
Yes. The philosophy of language is an interesting topic. Professor is dedicated to teaching.

If you are interested in Phil. of language then yes, I do feel like I have a foundational understanding of a wide range of topics in the field. On the other hand if you are looking for a one-off Philosophy class I wouldn't necessarily recommend it, I think the discussion was often pretty narrow and felt pretty low-stakes.

If you're a linguistics or philosophy student, yes. This class will broaded your view of both fields -- but if you're not into philosophy or linguistics, the questions this class asks might seem strange.
